title: 110_s2471
content: The Act may be cited as the "USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007" and includes reforms to the USERRA complaint process. The USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007 includes amendments to expedite the investigation and resolution of complaints. The Secretary must notify complainants of their rights within 5 days and complete actions within 90 days of receiving a complaint. Technical assistance can be provided to claimants and their employers upon request. The USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007 includes amendments to expedite complaint resolution. The Secretary must complete actions within 90 days of receiving a complaint. Referrals to the Attorney General or special counsel must be done within 15 days. Notification of representation by the Attorney General is required. The USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007 requires the Attorney General to make a decision on representation within 45 days of receiving a referral, and notify the individual of this decision. The Special Counsel must also make a decision within 45 days of receiving a referral. The USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007 mandates that the Special Counsel must decide on representation within 45 days of receiving a referral and inform the individual of the decision. SEC. 3. EXPANSION OF REPORTING REQUIREMENTS FOR USERRA ENFORCEMENT. Expansion of reporting requirements for USERRA enforcement includes amending Section 4332 of title 38, United States Code to specify the number of cases reviewed by the Secretary of Defense through the National Committee for Employer Support of the Guard and Reserve of the Department of Defense during the fiscal year. It also requires reporting on cases involving the same person seeking employment or reemployment, as well as cases with disability-related issues. The amendment to Section 4332 of title 38, United States Code expands reporting requirements for USERRA enforcement. It specifies the number of cases reviewed by the Secretary of Defense through the National Committee for Employer Support of the Guard and Reserve of the Department of Defense during the fiscal year. The amendment also includes reporting on cases involving the same person seeking employment or reemployment, as well as cases with disability-related issues. The amendment to Section 4332 of title 38, United States Code expands reporting requirements for USERRA enforcement. It adds a new subsection requiring the Comptroller General to submit quarterly reports to Congress, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel. The report must include the number of cases where the Secretary did not meet requirements, cases where referrals were not made on time, and other relevant case statistics. The amendment to Section 4332 of title 38, United States Code requires the Comptroller General to submit quarterly reports on USERRA enforcement. The reports must include cases where referrals were not made on time and cases where requirements were not met by the Secretary, Attorney General, and Special Counsel. The amendment to Section 4332 of title 38, United States Code mandates uniform categorization of data for USERRA enforcement. It requires coordination between various departments to ensure consistent reporting and electronic access to case files. The amendments apply to reports after the enactment of the Act.
